citeinfo.origin: Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab, The University of Montana
citeinfo.title: Montana Amphibian, Reptile, and Mammal Distributions by Hexagon

pubinfo.publish: Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab, The University of Montana

descript.abstract:
BACKGROUND
Distributional limits are a necessary ingredient of the vertebrate modeling process for gap analysis: they allow us to place bounds on where a species is predicted to occur. For Montana Gap Analysis (MT-GAP), we delineated known distributions for species in two ways: latilongs for birds, and hexagons for all other species.
Latilongs (one-degree blocks of latitude and longitude) are units that are fairly commonly used to document species presence or absence across a state. The 49 latilong blocks within Montana offer the advantage of an equal-area sampling structure, but average 7977 sq km apiece (calculated in Albers equal-area projection). Thus, they are likely to overestimate a species' distribution where its range extends only partly into a latilong.
Another option that alleviates this problem is the EPA's hexagon grid system, based on units 635 sq km in size (White et al. 1992); Montana contains all or part of 656 hexagons. For Montana, hexagon distribution maps were created for amphibians, reptiles, and mammals. However, because of project constraints, for birds we opted to use an existing system based on latilongs (Montana Bird Distribution Committee 1996). Because of this difference in units, a single bird observation is extrapolated across a larger area than observations for other species; in essence, amphibian, reptile, and mammal distributions are mapped at a finer resolution.
HOW HEXAGONS WERE POPULATED
Distributional limits for amphibians, reptiles, and mammals were mapped using the hexagon grid system (White et al. 1992). The Montana Natural Heritage Program (MTNHP) was contracted to compile point locations and populate EPA hexagons as outlined by Master et al. (1994) for each species in these taxonomic groups, and to deliver both in GIS databases: a point coverage for species' observations, and a series of INFO tables for species' status within hexagons. What follows is a description of MTNHP's methods, as well as notes on how data were reviewed and used for MT-GAP.
Point observations of these terrestrial vertebrates were compiled from the following sources: museum specimens, published literature, unpublished reports and theses, existing MTNHP databases, wildlife observations recorded by agency and independent biologists, and a U.S. Forest Service database on carnivores. Sources were entered into the MTNHP bibliographic database and given a unique identifier called SOURCECODE. The approximately 16,000 records of herptiles and mammals compiled came from the following sources: ca. 8600 are specimens; ca. 800 are from published accounts; ca. 3000 are from unpublished (gray literature) accounts; ca. 1000 are from other databases; and ca. 2500 are from sightings by individuals.
Species observations were entered into the MTNHP Point Observation Database (POD). This database, currently maintained using Microsoft Access software, stores information on the species, source (SOURCECODE), date, observer, type of record (sighting, specimen, 'heard only', etc.), breeding status, and other details of the observation.
All available locational information was also entered into POD: descriptive, coordinate (UTM or geographic), or Public Land Survey System (PLSS, or township/range/section). The locational information was then assessed to determine (a) how best (most accurately and efficiently) to generate a point feature for that observation and (b) the precision (measured in meters) of the locational information. For example, an observation reported to a quarter section would have a data precision of ca. 500 meters, since a point generated in the center of that quarter section would be at most 500 meters from the actual location. However, an observation with only a descriptive location (e.g., 20 miles south of Fort Musselshell) could have a data precision of as much as 40,000 meters. In every case, the point feature is created in as accurate a location as possible; so, for the above example, MTNHP staff would measure exactly 20 miles due south from their best estimate of Fort Musselshell's location.
Observations with descriptive locations only were mapped onto a mylar overlay of a 1:500,000 scale map of Montana that was mounted on foam board, and the points were later digitized. For observations with PLSS locations, points were digitized on-screen, using the BLM's 1:100,000 scale PLSS coverage to guide placement of the point. For observations with coordinate locations, points were generated in ARC/INFO.
When this work began, the POD system already contained ca. 4700 observations of herptiles and mammals. Many of these had been entered by mapping point locations onto mylar overlays of a 1:1,000,000 map of Montana, or overlays of the various National Forest Visitor Maps that cover parts of Montana. These pre-GAP observations had been assigned to three precision classes, rather than estimating the actual (im)precision in meters. Also, for many observations, the precision with which they were mapped, and the points generated, were worse (a greater distance) than their inherent data precision. For example, a museum specimen card might say 'west of Highwood,' but also give a PLSS location to the section. That point, mapped on a 1:1,000,000 mylar overlay, would have a mapping precision of ca. 3000 meters, but a data precision of ca. 1000 meters. So at the start of this project, MTNHP staff retrofitted all existing observations with both their data and mapping precisions, and then re-mapped many of those for which the mapping precision was greater (less precise) than the data precision. After entering the data into POD and creating a unique point feature for all observations, MTNHP staff used an overlay analysis to create an initial hexagon status map for each species. Each point was first buffered by its data precision, then overlayed with the EMAP hexagon coverage. If a certain hexagon contained 95% or more of the area of a buffered point, the species represented by that point was considered 'confirmed' in that hexagon (Table 1). If only 80-95% of the area occurred in one hex, that hexagon was coded as 'probable' for that species. For 10-80% overlap, it was coded 'possible', and for less than 10% overlap it was not coded at all. Note that under this scheme a single observation could result in up to seven hexagons being coded as 'possible' for that species. (An observation mapped in roughly the center of a hexagon with a data precision of ca. 40 km would overlay seven hexagons, each containing roughly 14% of its buffered area.)
_____________________________________________________________________________
TABLE 1. Confidence levels assigned to hexagons for each amphibian, reptile, and mammal.
1. CONFIRMED. >95% of an observation's buffered area*** within the hexagon, or professional estimate of greater than 95% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.
2. PROBABLE. 80-95% of an observation's buffered area within the hexagon, or professional estimate of 80-95% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.
3. POSSIBLE. 10-80% of an observation's buffered area within the hexagon, or professional estimate of 10-80% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.
4. HISTORICAL. Reported prior to 1950 (status based on that 'historical' report could be 1, 2, or 3).
5. EXCLUDED. Eliminated based on professional judgment. Mostly accidentals: observations likely to be migrating or dispersing individuals; habitat and/or area could not sustain the species. Occasionally, misidentifications detected after initial hexagon population.
*** 'Buffered area' means the area created by buffering the point location for each observation by its data precision, as expressed in meters (i.e., the more imprecise the data, the larger the precision and the larger the buffered area). ________________________________________________________________________________
It is important to keep in mind just what the words 'probable' and 'possible' mean in this context. There are no uncertain records in POD -- observations which are questionable as to species are not entered. The uncertainty, and hence the use of 'probable' and 'possible' vis-a-vis hard (POD) data, relates only to locational accuracy. In the example above, the species was definitely observed (i.e., is confirmed) somewhere in that 7-hexagon area; but one cannot say with certainty in which particular hexagon it occurred.
The result of this analysis was an intermediate data file that contained a record for each POD-point/hexagon overlap. That file was then queried to retrieve the best record ('confirmed' better than 'probable' better than 'possible') for each species in each hexagon, and data from that record were entered into the INFO files STATUS.DATA and SOURCE.DATA. Each are matrices of Montana's 656 hexagons (records) by its 148 mammals and herptiles (fields). The STATUS.DATA file was then used to produce draft maps for each species that showed its status in each hexagon. The SOURCE.DATA file contained the unique identifier, or SOURCECODE, for the source of the observation that supported that species' status in that hexagon. For game animals, digital distribution data from the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife & Parks (MTFWP) was also used to create additional species/hexagon overlap records. These records have as their source "DFWP_9705".
The draft hexagon status maps were then subjected to in-house review at MTNHP. Mammals were reviewed by J. Reichel, P. Hendricks, and P. Feigley; amphibians and reptiles by J. Reichel, P. Hendricks, B. Maxell, and C. Peterson. Reviewers used their personal knowledge of the species and published range maps for Montana and adjacent areas to update the hexagon distributions based on professional judgment. For amphibians and reptiles, where documented locations tended to be sparse, the following rules were used:
1. Extensions of a species' range beyond documented locations were made conservatively unless: a) published records in adjacent states and territories suggested a continuous range to the state border; b) published articles, theses, or dissertations with reliable records suggested a range extension; or c) as a function of computer processing, hexagons adjacent to a confirmed hexagon were included when a modeled habitat type was continuous across the confirmed hexagon and its neighbor.
2. Hexagons within the known range of a species were included liberally, even without documented presence. The assumption was made that the modeling process would later eliminate unlikely habitat within the range (e.g., exclusion of a mountain range).
For more information on amphibians and reptiles, please see Appendix 3.1 in Redmond et al. (1998), and also individual species accounts in Hart et al. (1998).
A variety of sources were consulted when editing hexagon maps for mammals, including maps (MTFWP atlas of ungulate and mountain lion distributions) and published information (Hoffmann and Pattie 1968, Banfield 1974, Turner 1974, Hall 1981, Clark and Stromberg 1987, Smith 1989, Pattie and Hoffmann 1992, Buskirk et al. 1994, Groves et al. 1997). Also, for all species, input was sought from knowledgeable individuals. In addition, T. Kohley (WY-GAP) was consulted on hexagon population for wide-ranging mammals and bats.
Hexagons were edited to better reflect species' known or expected distributions. For some wide-ranging mammals, this meant overriding actual location data (see definition for Status 5, Table 1). Examples include observations of wolverine (Gulo gulo) in the Billings vicinity, and of moose (Alces alces) along the Yellowstone River in eastern Montana, near the North Dakota border.
Based on in-house review by MTNHP, additional species/hexagon overlap records were created and stored in a separate data file. These records generally raised the status of a species in a particular hex. For example, suppose species A in hexagon 1 was ranked as 'possible' based on actual observations entered into POD; but the reviewer felt that its status was at least 'probable' in that hex. He or she would create that new record (species A in hexagon 1 = 'probable'), and attach his or her personal SOURCECODE to that record. Occasionally, reviewers wanted to overwrite observation data based on transient, dispersing or migrating individuals. If so, he or she could create a new record as above that would essentially erase POD-based records when generating the hexagon status files.
All of these editing changes were then added to the species/hexagon overlap records generated from POD data and a final query was run to retrieve the best record for each species in each hexagon and appropriately code the STATUS.DATA and SOURCE.DATA files. Note that additional observations were being entered into POD, and existing POD data were being remapped, while the review process was occurring. Because of this, in some cases reviewers' records that elevated a 'possible' to 'probable' were in turn superseded by newer POD data that confirmed the species' presence in a hexagon.
Later, once data had been passed to MT-GAP staff, these species-hexagon range maps were again reviewed, this time for MT-GAP by biologists from around the state. Reviewers were given the opportunity to make changes to individual hexagon occurrences if they questioned the assigned codes. They were also given the opportunity to add new locations to the database.
Species-hexagon range maps were then ready to be used as inputs to the final vertebrate modeling process. It should be noted that this is the only manner in which these particular maps were used for MT-GAP. Maps of species richness within hexagons were created after distributions were predicted, and do not reflect sums based on hexagons at this stage. See Redmond et al. (1998) for more information.
THE GIS DATABASE
HEXGRID is one of the primary inputs to the vertebrate modeling process for MT-GAP. It is a 90 m ARC/INFO grid (raster file) that maps distributions for 144 amphibian, reptile, and mammal species by hexagon. Of these 144 species, 135 were included in the vertebrate modeling process. The other 9, including species that are either exotic, extirpated, or potentially occurring in the state, were not modeled.
In HEXGRID, each species is identified by its element code, a unique identifier defined by The Nature Conservancy. Within the GIS database, 144 separate items (i.e., element codes) indicate each species' presence within each of 656 hexagons in the state, using the 7 codes above. Hexagons are identified by the VALUE and HEX_ID items (which are identical and therefore somewhat redundant).
For more information on the MT-GAP modeling process, please refer to the Montana Gap Analysis Final Report (Redmond et al. 1998). Habitat accounts, species distribution maps, references, and modeling rules are found in the Montana Atlas of Terrestrial Vertebrates (Hart et al. 1998). Both are available digitally in Adobe Acrobat PDF format.
The CITATIONS
Banfield, A.W.F. 1974. The mammals of Canada. Univ. Toronto Press. 438 pp.
Buskirk, S.W., A.S. Harestad, M.G. Raphael, and R.A. Powell, eds. 1994. Martens, sables, and fishers: biology and conservation. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca. 501 pp.
Clark, T.W. and M.R. Stromberg. 1987. Mammals in Wyoming. Univ. Kans. Mus. Nat. Hist. Publ. Educ. Serv.; No. 10. 314 pp.
Groves, C.R., B. Butterfield, A. Lippincott, B. Csuti, and J.M. Scott. 1997. Atlas of Idaho's Wildlife. Idaho Dept. Fish and Game, Boise, Idaho. 372 pp.
Hall, E.R. 1981. The mammals of North America, 2d ed. (2 vols.). John Wiley and Sons, New York.
Hart, M.M., W.A. Williams, P.C. Thornton, K.P. McLaughlin, C.M. Tobalske, B.A. Maxell, D.P. Hendricks, C.R. Peterson, and R.L. Redmond. 1998. Montana atlas of terrestrial vertebrates. Unpublished report. Montana Cooperative Wildlife Research Unit, The University of Montana, Missoula. vii + 1302 pp.
Hoffmann, R.S. and D.L. Pattie. 1968. A guide to Montana mammals: identification, habitat, distribution, and abundance. University of Montana, Missoula. 133 pp.
Master, L., N. Clupper, E. Gaines, C. Boget, R. Solomon, and M. Ormes. 1994. Biodiversity Research Consortium species database manual (12/23/94 edition). The Nature Conservancy, Boston, Mass.
Montana Bird Distribution Committee. 1996. P.D. Skaar's Montana Bird Distribution, Fifth Edition. Special Publication No. 3. Montana Natural Heritage Program, Helena. 130 pp.
Pattie, D.L. and R.S. Hoffmann. 1992. Mammals of the North American Parks and Prairies, 2d ed. Privately published, Edmonton, Alberta. 579 pp.
Redmond, R.L., M.M. Hart, J.C. Winne, W.A. Williams, P.C. Thornton, Z. Ma, C.M. Tobalske, M.M. Thornton, K.P. McLaughlin, T.P. Tady, F.B. Fisher, S.W. Running. 1998. The Montana Gap Analysis Project: final report. Unpublished report. Montana Cooperative Wildlife Research Unit, The University of Montana, Missoula. xiii + 136 pp. + appendices.
Smith, H.C. 1989. Checklist of the mammals of Alberta, revised ed. Provincial Museum of Alberta, Edmonton. 14 pp.
Turner, R.W. 1974. Mammals of the Black Hills of South Dakota and Wyoming. Univ. Kans. Mus. Nat. Hist. Misc. Publ.; No. 60. 178 pp.
White, D., J. Kimerling, and W.S. Overton. 1992. Cartographic and geometric components of a global sampling design for environmental monitoring. Cartographic and Geographic Information Systems 19:5-22.
MISCELLANEOUS
Note that these data also exist as an ARC/INFO coverage called HEX. This coverage can readily be recreated in ARC/INFO using the GRIDPOLY command.
The following metadata elements are required by GAP, but do not parse using the FGDC ms parser (although similar elements can be found later in this document for several of these). For the convenience of GAP users, these elements are listed here. Data Set Identity: HEXGRID; Raster File Format: ARC/INFO GRID; Raster File Sensor: NA; Vector File Format: NA; Nonspatial File Format: NA; Source Distance Resolution: 90 meters; Raster File Number of Bytes per Pixel: 4; Native Data Structure: Raster.
descript.purpose: These data were produced to map amphibian, reptile, and mammal distributions in a standardized, consistent manner across the state for use in Montana Gap Analysis. Hexagon distributions were used to limit predicted habitat to areas within each species' known range.

idinfo.accconst: This data set is in the public domain, and the recipient may not assert any proprietary rights thereto nor represent it to anyone as other than a dataset produced by Montana Natural Heritage Program, and updated and managed by the Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab.
idinfo.useconst: This data set is provided "as-is" without warranty of any kind, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. The user assumes all responsibility for the accuracy and suitability of this data set for a specific application. In no event will the creators, The University of Montana, or the US Geological Survey be liable for any damages, including lost profits, lost savings, or other incidental or consequential damages arising from the use of or inability to use this data set. Use of these data requires the ability to read Arc/Info Grid data sets. Users must assume responsibility for determining the suitability of these data for their purposes. Not for use at scales greater than 1:100000.

cntorgp.cntorg: Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab, The University of Montana

cntaddr.address: Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab, The University of Montana

browse.browsed: Sample image of the data set and/or its extent.

idinfo.datacred: The Montana Natural Heritage Program for creating the dataset. The Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab for updating and managing it as part of the overall Montana Gap Analysis dataset. Cedron Jones, MTNHP, provided the bulk of the documentation used in the abstract (above); special thanks to him, to all the MTNHP staff, and to all MT-GAP reviewers for their contributions.
idinfo.native: The Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab uses IBM RS/6000 Workstations running AIX 4.1 with Arc/Info software versions 7.04 and 7.11, Erdas version 7.5, and Imagine version 8.1.

attracc.attraccr: Not assessed by Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab. Within the dataset, codes indicate the level of confidence placed in the occurrence of each species within each hexagon (based on the locational accuracy of a reported observation, professional judgment, or both). See Table 1 in the abstract above. Initial hexagon population was based only on actual observations; furthermore, any questionable observations were not used to populate hexagons. However, because reported observations for many species are sparse and patchy, species presence within hexagons was also assessed based on professional judgment. Without obtaining additional observations, it is impossible to assess the accuracy of those judgment calls.

dataqual.logic: All grid attributes were checked for consistency of appropriate range values.
dataqual.complete: All areas in Montana are included in this layer; in fact, hexagons extend beyond state boundaries in many areas.

citeinfo.title: Hexagon Distributions for Amphibians, Reptiles, and Mammals.

srcinfo.srccontr: Final version of a dataset to which much of this metadata document is dedicated; produced by MTNHP under contract to The University of Montana's Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab. Described in detail in the above abstract. Provided the base-level hexagon maps that were then reviewed and updated for Montana Gap Analysis.

citeinfo.title: Expert review of predicted species distributions for Montana Gap Analysis.

pubinfo.pubplace: Hardcopy comments on file at Wildlife Spatial Analysis Lab, Missoula, Montana.

srcinfo.srccontr: Provided additional species observations to supplement MTNHP's populated hexagons, as well as commentary on the hexagon maps for each species. Maps were reviewed by more than 50 biologists from around the state; for a complete list, see Appendix 3.2, Redmond et al. (1998).

pubinfo.pubplace: Oregon State University/US EPA, Corvallis, Oregon.

srcinfo.srccontr: Spatial data -- the hexagon boundaries themselves -- were acquired from a site called "The EMAP Hexagon Grid" on the Links page of the National Gap homepage (http://www.gap.uidaho.edu/Links/). The ARC/INFO export file "ushexes.poly.geo.e00" was downloaded from ftp://morpheus.cor.epa.gov/pub/WB/denis/emapgrid/ on 26 March 1997. (The current site is ftp://cerberus.epa.orst.edu/pub/WB/denis/emapgrid/, but the date of the *.e00 file (3/3/94) is the same as it was in 1997.)

procstep.procdesc: ACQUIRE SPECIES DATA: from Montana Natural Heritage Program, acquire INFO files that indicate the likelihood that each amphibian, reptile, or mammal is found in each hexagon. Populating hexagons was an iterative process, so several copies were acquired over time; the final version was acquired in April 1998.

CREATE HEXAGON GRID: Download ARC/INFO export file from EPA ftp site. Import data to an ARC/INFO coverage, then project from geographic coordinates to Albers equal-area projection. At this point, the coverage contains all hexagons for the Lower 48 states. Identify hexagons that overlap with the Montana border and put them in a separate coverage. Convert to grid format, using "setmask" and "setwindow" commands so that the grid's extent and pixel increment match all other MT-GAP grids. Attach attributes to the grid using the JOINITEM command (relate item = HEX_ID).

UPDATE: modify/update database slightly to make more suitable for MT-GAP purposes, e.g., ensure match between element codes in the hexagon database and those downloaded from TNC webpage in November 1997. Incorporate species observations reported and comments made by biologists from around the state during the expert review process. Modify INFO data table HEXSOURCE.DAT so that changes suggested by reviewers can be tracked.

attr.attrdef: the Identifier for each of the 656 hexagons that fall entirely or partly within Montana's borders. Maintained from the original data downloaded from EPA, so identifiers nest within overall coding structure for 48 conterminous states. Same as HEX_ID item.
Number of 90m x 90m pixels per hexagon. Mean count is 79715 pixels/hexagon.

The Identifier for each of the 656 hexagons that fall entirely or partly within Montana's borders. Maintained from the original data downloaded from EPA, so identifiers nest within overall coding structure for 48 conterminous states. Same as VALUE item.

ELCODE is a generic name for the remaining set of 144 attributes (one per species; see below). Attribute names are element codes (used by The Nature Conservancy) for each species; they identify confidence levels for species occurrence in each hexagon. For example, AAAAA01080 indicates confidence levels per hexagon for the long-toed salamander. Not all species in the hexagon database were included in the MT-GAP modeling process; some are exotic in the state, etc.
Definitions for actual attribute values can be found in Table 1 in the abstract. They are also provided at the end of the list below, which links attribute names (i.e., element codes) with scientific and common names for each species:

edom.edomvd:
CONFIRMED: >95% of an observation's buffered area within the hexagon, or professional estimate of >95% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.
For values 1-3, "buffered area" means the area created by buffering the point location for each observation by its data precision, as expressed in meters (i.e., the more imprecise the data, the larger the precision and the larger the buffered area.
PROBABLE: 80-95% of an observation's buffered area within the hexagon, or professional estimate of 80-95% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.
POSSIBLE: 10-80% of an observation's buffered area within the hexagon, or professional estimate of 10-80% probability that the species occurs within the hexagon.

EXCLUDED: Eliminated based on professional judgment. Mostly accidentals: observations likely to be migrating or dispersing individuals; habitat and/or area could not sustain the species. Occasionally, misidentifications detected after initial hexagon population.

attr.attrdef: The Identifier for each of the 656 hexagons that fall entirely or partly within Montana's borders. Maintained from the original data downloaded from EPA, so identifiers nest within overall coding structure for 48 conterminous states.

ELCODE is a generic name for the remaining set of 144 attributes (one per species, just as outlined above for HEXGRID.VAT). As above, these attribute names are element codes for each species. Element codes identify the source of the data provided for each hexagon so that users can differentiate between observations recorded in the original database provided by MTNHP (MTNHP_HEX) and updates made during the MT-GAP review process.

attrdomv.udom:
Actual attribute values are source codes as defined by MTNHP (and by The Nature Conservancy as a whole). Based on instructions obtained from MTNHP on 12/3/96, source codes are generally determined by the following 12-digit structure: 1) source type; 2-3) year; 4-6) first three letters of author's last name; 7-8) tie-breaker (usually indicates the entry number for that author in that year); 9-10) state; and 11-12) nation. For example, "P98GAP01MTUS" indicates source type = person, year = 1998, author = GAP (short for GAP reviewers in this instance), tie-breaker = 01 (the first entry in 1998 for GAP), state = Montana, and nation = USA.
Source types include: A (article in journal or chapter in book); B (book); F (field survey); I (illustrations and photos); J (relevant journal titles, not to be used for articles appearing in journals); M (maps and remote sensing); N (non-standard published documents, including occasional papers, conference proceedings, etc.); 0 (organizations, agencies, institutions, or collections); P (person whose individual knowledge or expertise constitutes the basis for the source); S (specimen); U (unpublished materials including unpublished theses and dissertations); and E (electronic sources such as internet homepages or email messages).
A complete list of source codes is unavailable, but users can identify hexagons based on professional judgment as those with source codes beginning with "P". For example, "P97FEI01MTUS" indicates a professional judgment call made by P. Feigley in 1997. All comments made by MT-GAP reviewers are denoted by "P98GAP01MTUS", as outlined above.
